Example.Title: Listview with Kendo UI
Example.Lead: The simplest way to use JayData and KendoUI is creating a listview. All you need is a JayData context, of course it works with all providers! In this example OData is used.
Example.Description:
As you can see in this example, to use Kendo UI with JayData is a piece of cake. All you need is a JayData context, of course it works with all providers! In this example OData is used.
Check the network panel to see the requests. You can create a Kendo Datasource with a simple method: asKendoDataSource() and off you go. If works everywhere where Kendo expects a DataSource, not only with ListView. Our datasource supports everything, so paging, filtering and sorting all works. If you use oData, then paging, filtering and sorting happens on the server side! asKendoDataSource() is a method of Queryable so you can use all features of JayData, filtering, projection, etc.
Example.Meta-KeyWords: JayData, KendoUI, Crossplatform, Javascript, HTML5, tutorial, example
Example.Meta-Description: How to create JayData listview with Kendo UI? See this simple listview example.

Example.Title: Kendo UI listview with filter and sorting
Example.Lead: JayData and Kendo UI listview with filtering and sorting. The dataSource supports paging, filtering and sorting without writing storage or protocol-specific code.
Example.Description:
As you can see in this example, to use Kendo UI with JayData is a piece of cake. All you need is a JayData context, of course it works with all providers! In this example oData is used. Check the network panel to see the requests. You can create a Kendo Datasource with a simple method: asKendoDataSource() and off you go.
If works everywhere where Kendo expects a DataSource, not only with ListView. Our datasource supports everything, so paging, filtering and sorting all works. If you use oData, then paging, filtering and sorting happens on the server side! asKendoDataSource() is a method of Queryable so you can use all features of JayData, filtering, projection, etc.
Example.Meta-KeyWords: JayData, HTML5, Kendo UI, HTML5 datasource, Javascript, example
Example.Meta-Description: How to use the JayData with Kendo UI? See this listview example.
Example.Tags: KendoUI, OData, query, JayStorm, sort, list

Example.Title: Kendo UI grid with filter and sorting
Example.Lead: Simple Kendo UI grid with remote OData datasource. Sorting, paging and filtering works on the server side but with a simple switch they can be one the client side, too.
Example.Description: This Kendo Grid example uses oData to access the Northwind service. Sorting, paging and filtering works on the server side but with a simple switch they can be one the client side, too. In this example the grid is read only and the columns are manually configured. In other examples you'll see read-write grid and automatic column setup.
Example.Meta-KeyWords: JayData, HTML5, Javascript, Kendo UI, Crossplatform, WebSQL, IndexedDB, example
Example.Meta-Description: How to use the JayData with Kendo UI? See this simple grid example.
Example.Tags: KendoUI, OData, query, sort, Northwind, grid

Example.Title: Kendo UI grid and CRUD
Example.Lead: Create, read, update and delete in-browser database records in Kendo UI grid. JayData knows how to process the CRUD actions and translate it to different data storage syntaxes.
Example.Description: This Kendo Grid example uses a local Northwind database. Sorting, paging and filtering works along with full CRUD. The demo is written so that your local database is reinitialized on every page reload and your changes are lost!
Example.Meta-KeyWords: JayData, HTML5, Javascript, Kendo UI, Crossplatform, example
Example.Meta-Description: How to use the JayData with Kendo UI! See this simple example.

Example.Title: Kendo UI Northwind product browser app
Example.Lead: Populate categorized products in Kendo UI ListView from live OData service using JayData. Filter and order records with JSQL syntax and apply projection to reduce network payload.
Example.Description: This Kendo mobile example uses a remote Northwind database over OData. asKendoDataSource() is a method of Queryable, so not only an EntitySet can be specified but other JayData expressions as well. The projection on the Categories set reduces the network traffic because pictures won't be downloaded (we only display the name of the category so pictures are not needed). Be sure to include the primary key into the map! The filter on the Products set filters out records on the server so products that are not in stock won't be displayed. It also sorts the products on the server side. When KendoUI widget also filters and sorts the records (such as grid), the filtering and ordering specified at datasource definition and the filtering and ordering specified by the KendoUI widget are combined.
Example.Meta-KeyWords: JayData, HTML5, Kendo UI, OData service, OData, Javascript, mobile app, Northwind, example
Example.Meta-Description: How to use the JayData with Kendo UI? See this simple example.

Example.Meta-KeyWords: JayData, HTML5, Javascript, Kendo UI, oData, WebSQL, IndexedDB, example
Example.Meta-Description: How to use the JayData with Kendo UI? See this simple example.

Example.Title: Knockout data binding
Example.Lead: Demonstrating easy data binding using JayData and Knockout.js together. Properties of the requested entities will be observable through a single toArray call if ko.observableArray is passed as parameter.
Example.Description: JayData examples: Knockout model binding & Observable results and entities. Demonstrating easy data binding using JayData and Knockout.js together. Properties of the requested entities will be observable through a single toArray call if ko.observableArray is passed as parameter.

Example.Title: Knockout Dynamic Queries
Example.Lead: With the JayData module for Knockout.js you can achieve fully dynamic queries. Where you use an observable as a query parameter the query will be automatically executed when the observable property changes.
Example.Description: With the JayData module for Knockout.js you can achieve fully dynamic queries. Where you use an observable as a query parameter the query will be automatically executed when the observable property changes..

Example.Title: Planets - HTML5 app
Example.Lead: Local database management through the WebSQL provider, in a fancy representative HTML5 app. It uses new features of CSS3 like keyframe-animations, transitions and transformations.
Example.Description:
In this sample application, the planets are just plain DIV elements, with tricky, but simple CSS3 styling on them. A circle can be easily made by using the border-radius property and some fancy looking colorized box-shadow style applied, just to be more than plain filled circles.
The rotating animation of the planets is simple with the use of the native keyframe-animation CSS3 feature of modern browser engines like WebKit.
Stacking the DIVs together, we can create a simple representation of complex solar systems.
Example.Tags: WebSQL, SQLite, CRUD, HTML5 localStorage, query
Example.Meta-KeyWords: JayData, JayData providers, OData, Crossplatform, HTML5, WebSQL, SQLite, Javascript, HTML5, tutorial, example
Example.Meta-Description: How to create a HTML5 app with JayData? See this simple example.

RelatedContents.ContentLink: Planets: sample application using JayData’s WebSQL provider

Example.Title: JayScrum - agile task manager app
Example.Lead: This application built on JayData on the JayStorm, it serves its role as a fine example for an application with provisioned database. Through this application you can manage Projects, Backlogs, Tasks, Bugs, and Impediments.
Example.Description: JayScrum is a cross-platform, cross-device application which enables agile software development teams to work utilizing the SCRUM discipline with the help of mobile or tablet devices. It handles SCRUM’s meetings, artifacts and roles. Besides being a great project management tool (which we use ourselves) built on JayData and JayStorm, it serves its role as a fine example for an application with provisioned database.
Example.Tags: WebSQL, indexedDB, JayStorm, Knockout, OData, CRUD, query
Example.Meta-KeyWords: JayData, JayData providers, indexedDb, Crossplatform, Javascript, HTML5, tutorial, WebSQL, HTML5 localStorage provider, example
Example.Meta-Description: How to create a full cycle task manager app? See this amazing example.

RelatedContents.ContentLink: How to achieve your financial goals with JayStorm?

Example.Title: Flower Shop - Windows8 application
Example.Lead: This example shows you how to create a simple, full cycle Windows8 Eshop application with cloudbased data backend.
Example.Description: This example shows you how to create a simple, full cycle Windows8 Eshop application with cloudbased data backend. We will use the JayStorm Application Manager to setup the schema of the online data store. To create the product database we will use the JayStorm Data Manager. On the client we will use JayData and knockoutjs to implement the simple product browsing and place order use cases.

Example.Title: TodoList with transaction - multiple pro-providers
Example.Lead: Use JayData Pro providers if you need transactionality. See this todo-list example with basic transaction handling.
Example.Description:
TodoList with transaction example where you can create, edit or delete task items, but the value of task item is unique. The validation and a save processes use the same transaction so this assures the atomic running.
Two providers are supported: WebSQL, IndexedDB.
Supported browsers for IndexedDB: Internet Explorer:10+ Mozilla Firefox:10+ Google Chrome:12+ Windows phone:8+

Example.Title: TodoList complex - multiple pro-providers
Example.Lead: Use JayData Pro providers if you create robust application. See this todo-list example which introduces advanced indices and transaction handling.
Example.Description:
ToDoList with categories example where you can create, edit or delete task items and there categories. We use readonly/write transactions and database index to make a performance and robust app. In this usecase we save task items with category. Categories are unique in the database, and each category has at least one task. Two providers are supported: WebSQL and IndexedDB.
Supported browsers for IndexedDB: Internet Explorer:10+ Mozilla Firefox:10+ Google Chrome:12+ Windows phone:8+

Example.Title: Geography example with Google Maps
Example.Lead: Show geography points on Google Maps. JayData supports GeoJSON compliant geography and geometry types.
Example.Description: JayData supports GeoJSON compliant geography and geometry types. On local providers and on oData store/retrieve is supported, oData provider also supports geo querying if the backend supports it. JayStorm 1.1+ and JayService 1.3+ with MongoDB Pro as oData backend supports geo querying. The received data is of GeoJSON type, unfortunatelly Google Maps does not supports it natively so we have to use a converter.
Example.Meta-KeyWords: JayData, JayData providers, Crossplatform, Javascript, HTML5, tutorial, geography, geometry, example
Example.Meta-Description: Use GeoJSON compliant oData service with Google Maps! See this simple example.

Example.Title: Geography example with Leaflet.js
Example.Lead: Show geography points using leaflet.js. JayData supports GeoJSON compliant geography and geometry types.
Example.Description: JayData supports GeoJSON compliant geography and geometry types. On local providers and on oData store/retrieve is supported, oData provider also supports geo querying if the backend supports it. JayStorm 1.1+ and JayService 1.3+ with MongoDB Pro as oData backend supports geo querying. The received data is of GeoJSON type so we can use it with leafletjs directly.
Example.Meta-KeyWords: JayData, JayData providers, Crossplatform, Javascript, HTML5, tutorial, geography, geometry, example, leaflet, leafletjs
Example.Meta-Description: Use GeoJSON compliant oData service with Leaflet.js! See this simple example.

Example.Title: Geographical search over oData
Example.Lead: Show geography points within a circle using leafletjs.
Example.Description: Click onto the map. POIs within the radius set in the input box in meters are shown. Watch the network to see oData geo queries, the distance is sent in radians over oData.
